discussion.p: Currently std::ignore is not specified constexpr according to the C++ draft N4606 in the paragraph . It prevents some use in constexpr context: for example declaring a constexpr variable equals to the result of a function to which std::ignore has been passed as a parameter:

blockquote.pre: constexpr int i = f(std::ignore); // Won't compile

discussion.p: If there is no fundamental reason preventing std::ignore to be constexpr, then we propose to declare it as constexpr instead of as const.

resolution.p: This wording is relative to N4606.

blockquote.pre: // 20.5.2.4, tuple creation functions: constconstexpr unspecified ignore;
